Level 3 maths and English

Level 3 maths and English payment breakdown on a 1 year programme
Level 3 maths and English payment

Supports delivery of maths and English to students on substantial level 3 study programmes (including T Levels) who have not yet attained a grade 9 to 4 GCSE or equivalent in either or both of these subjects

 Payment per subject Instances per subject Total funded students Sub-total
Students on a 1 year eligible programme (less than 18 months) £375 0.11599 1,951 £83,859
Students on a 2 year eligible programme (18 months or more) £750 0.00311 1,951 £3,731
Total level 3 maths and English payment £87,590
More about level 3 maths and English payment

Where average instances comes from

Average instances are calculated using data from the October 2020 return (R14). A student gets one instance of funding if they do not have grade 4, C or higher in GCSE maths or English. Those without both GCSEs get 2 instances of funding.

Details are in your allocation calculation toolkit.

Total high needs
Places: 217 		217 £1,302,000
Where places comes from

Places are either rolled forward from 2020 to 2021 or your local authority agreed it with ESFA. This provides a base level of funding.

You must agree additional funding above this level with your local authority. Local authorities pay you the top-up funding directly. It is not shown in this statement.

More about amendments to high needs places

Discretionary bursary fund 2021 to 2022 {% if scenario == '1' %}£261,562.80{% elif scenario == '2' %}£381,008.70{% else %}£1,384,346{% endif %}
Where average instances come from

Average instances are calculated using data from the October 2020 return (R14) and the index of multiple deprivation 2019. Students are given an instance value for each funding element that is then averaged across total funded students.

Details are in your allocation calculation toolkit.

Adjusted discretionary bursary fund 2021 to 2022

From 2020 to 2021, the ESFA moved to a new methodology to calculate this fund. During the transition, you will receive between 50% and 150% of the amount you received in 2019 to 2020.
